newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore dollar sinks to 32-month low.
newsitem.headline: Singapore dollar sinks to 32-month low.

text.p: The Singapore dollar sank to a 32-month low of 1.4738 against the U.S. dollar on Thursday morning after stop losses were triggered at the 1.4700 level, said forex dealers.
The Sing dollar was last traded near these levels since mid-November 1994.
"Stop losses were triggered after it broke 1.4700 this morning," said the regional currency chief at a European bank.
He said the selling of the local currency had started on Wednesday following Finance Minister Richard Hu's comments in parliament on the Singapore dollar.
Hu had said that Singapore had a flexible exchange rate based on market demand.
He also said Singapore's export competitiveness has not been hurt by the recent weakness of some regional currencies against the Singapore dollar.
"The market read his remarks as that the Monetary Authority of Singapore was not concerned with the recent weakness in the Sing. The slide would be steady and gradual," said the dealer.
Selling this morning was by hedge funds and corporates after the stop losses were triggered above 1.4700, said dealers.
